Text: Buying stocks in a malarkey market
Imagine the gains youd make if you simply didnt invest in companies with scandals or sour sentiment.

BABA is up 25 over the past year while VOO is up 38 so thats not the success story youre making it out to be. Success in the market isnt just making a profit. If youre not beating the SP then youre losing. Bear in mind that while youre sitting on cash waiting for the next piece of bad news, that money isnt appreciating like it would with a set it and forget it approach. Also every time one of your picks starts to plateau and you decide to sell you have to give the tax man his cut which means you have less to reinvest. If you have to sell before youve owned the stock for a year then youll have to pay capital gains which will cut into your profit even more. All these things plus the fact that there isnt a guarantee that a stock will bounce back from bad news means that this is probably not the slam dunk you think it is. You may get lucky a few times but its probably not a sustainable investing strategy.
its an ETF world and we just live in it. results dont matter because of the sheer amount of macro spend in buying index and baskets. thats why mag7 and sp is unstoppable right now.

SMCI has been the most predictable downfall in the tech space in recent memory, in my opinion. In the enterprise IT world its considered a company youd get a quote from in order to return to your actual primary vendor Dell for ex. and get better pricing. Their warranty work was always contracted to subpar companies, their service is subpar, and the components often very budget choices from a system builder perspective. You just needed the cheaper quote from them in order to beat up your primary vendor a bit. One day they slap AI on their website and suddenly its 1000share for this mediocre CDW competitor, lol. That said I absolutely adore SMCI as a company because SMCI puts alone entirely paid for my new Model 3 Performance took delivery last week!.

Honestly, picking through the Hindenburg report. It all seems a bit off. The sources that they have selected are all disgruntled employees. None of them are from the financial side, they are claiming pipeline stuffing. Which is going to be extremely difficult to prove and likely overstated. Even if they are stuffing the pipeline, you can only stuff so much at the end of the month. Its unlikely that it would move the needle significantly. The individual that filed the lawsuit against SMCI was head of Customer Success and Support? How he would have a good understanding of the companies books is beyond me. It almost seems laughable. Additionally SMCI sales directors and senior sales directors are a dime a dozen. They have them everywhere inside and outside of North America. It is most likely that someone was terminated and has an ax to grind against the company. The allegations that they exported to Russia are completely false. They sold components to companies that then sold them to Russia. Thats not exporting to Russia, nor is that going to get them in hot water. At worst they have lost those companies as customers. If you look at the report, those sales represent a maximum of 200 million dollars in annual revenue or 40 million per quarter... Past charges for improperly recognized revenue was booked between 2016 and 2018 for a total of 200 million. Over 6 quarters that would be a total maximum of 33 million per quarter. The total fine as part of the SEC settlement was 16 million... total Margins for the company have been dropping and its potentially lost some market share to Dell. However the industry as a whole is growing, they are the third largest company, and as a group they will only be able to drive margins to a point. That point is very unlikely to be single digits. All this said, I bought shares at 400, and it seems like a really good deal in the long term. Unless every customer runs for the hills, these should pay of nicely. It always pays to do your research. Oh... the three employees that were terminated and then rehired. None of them have any anything to do with sales, accounting, or anything that could be construed as financial sway. I think its unlikely that anything substantial comes from the report and certainly nothing earth shattering

I didnt see this mentioned in the comments yet, but, premarketafterhours both mean next to nothing, and shouldnt be used as an indicator with any sense of confidence. Why is that, sometimes when something moves pre, post market, the trend remains. Yes, but a lot of times it doesnt. I wont get into the reasons too deeply here, but essentially the reason why stocks move differently in pre or post market compared to regular hours is liquidity. There are less shares being traded, and larger spreads on those shares being traded. Example You, as in YOU, can move the price of a 100 stock 1 or 1 by yourself with 100 shares by creating a ladder of sells incrememntally decreasing in value. Does that sound like something you could do with Google, or whatever other company youd like to use for this scenario during regular market hours? No. Essentially what Im saying is in my experience, trading outside of regular market hours should only be done when youre trying to save your ass on something thats going to get slammed when the market opens, and shouldnt be done without a good understanding of risk management.

SMCI is a great stock. It is a great stock. As a saying goes, people who never turns off the blinders of their windows always says so. SMCI is indeed a long term hold, the recent drop proves to give gold valuation to buyers who are not panicking to the DOJ. Peter Lynch once said, the greatest value creation from a stock, its when the news smells trouble on companies like SMCI assuming you feel its a great company like I do. Troubles always find where the money parks. Everyone who literally got into the AI fanatics are frenzy and craze about the drop that they become deluded about the price drop thinking there really is a problem with the stocks. Thats the whole purpose. Once everyone sold, the short seller will eventually buy back and get in, because its finally a lucrative for them to be longterm holder. As for retailer who are stuck at the level of 1000 or 800s? I am assuming they bail out when it dipped to 600 or 400. So that has always been the game, if you are one of the fews who caught the 400s congratulations. You deserve to be rewarded. As I say, there isnt wrong with SMCI fundamentals, people are just playing game at the wrong timing and getting burns. But thats how the game should play, otherwise, how does the rich get rich, or rather, how the big player makes money from small players? The hands gotta change... if everyone is holding the stock and none are selling, there is no liquidity. Remember, the stock market is a zero sum game. Same to forex and crypto, where there is a winner, there is a loser.

As the saying goes, those who close their blinds always claim they cant see. SMCI is a longterm hold, and the recent drop offers gold to buyers who arent rattled by the DOJ noise. Peter Lynch once said, the greatest value often arises when the headlines scream troubleassuming you believe in the company, like I do with SMCI. The markets panic is a playground for smart money. AI enthusiasts have lost their focus, deluding themselves into thinking the price drop signals a real problem. Thats the gameonce they sell in fear, the short sellers will buy back in, because thats when it becomes truly lucrative. Retail investors who jumped in at 1000 or 800 likely bailed out when it hit 600 or 400, and thats the cycle. If you caught the 400 range, congratulationsyouve positioned yourself for a reward. SMCIs fundamentals remain strong, but most are playing the game with poor timing and getting burned. Thats how the market workswealth shifts from those who panic to those with patience. If everyone held their stock, thered be no liquidity. The stock market, like forex and crypto, is a zerosum game. For every winner, theres a loser. The hands must change for the big players to profit.

No, you have no idea what youre talking about. Triple Witching was last week Friday. The next is on December 20th. Triple witching typically occurs on the third Friday of the months of March, June, September, and December. March 2024 The third Friday was March 15. June 2024 The third Friday was June 21. September 2024 The third Friday was September 20, which has already passed. Its always on the last trading day of the week when options contracts expire, which is usually a Friday unless theres a holiday. So stop spreading false information.

What Is TwoandTwenty? Many private equity firms charge a twoandtwenty fee structure. Fund investors must therefore pay 2 per year of assets under management AUM plus 20 of returns generated above a certain threshold known as the hurdle rate. They have an incentive namely 20 or more for returns generated above a threshold, and pumping up NVDA gains 1000, 2 trillion marketcap gain in the last 18 months is definitely going to help them get 20 plus bonus. Honestly, picking through the Hindenburg report. It all seems a bit off. The sources that they have selected are all disgruntled employees. None of them are from the financial side, they are claiming pipeline stuffing. Which is going to be extremely difficult to prove and likely overstated. Even if they are stuffing the pipeline, you can only stuff so much at the end of the month. Its unlikely that it would move the needle significantly. The individual that filed the lawsuit against SMCI was head of Customer Success and Support? How he would have a good understanding of the companies books is beyond me. It almost seems laughable. Additionally SMCI sales directors and senior sales directors are a dime a dozen. They have them everywhere inside and outside of North America. It is most likely that someone was terminated and has an ax to grind against the company. The allegations that they exported to Russia are completely false. They sold components to companies that then sold them to Russia. Thats not exporting to Russia, nor is that going to get them in hot water. At worst they have lost those companies as customers. If you look at the report, those sales represent a maximum of 200 million dollars in annual revenue or 40 million per quarter... Past charges for improperly recognized revenue was booked between 2016 and 2018 for a total of 200 million. Over 6 quarters that would be a total maximum of 33 million per quarter. The total fine as part of the SEC settlement was 16 million... total Margins for the company have been dropping and its potentially lost some market share to Dell. However the industry as a whole is growing, they are the third largest company, and as a group they will only be able to drive margins to a point. That point is very unlikely to be single digits. All this said, I bought shares at 400, and it seems like a really good deal in the long term. Unless every customer runs for the hills, these should pay of nicely. It always pays to do your research. Oh... the three employees that were terminated and then rehired. None of them have any anything to do with sales, accounting, or anything that could be construed as financial sway. I think its unlikely that anything substantial comes from the report and certainly nothing earth shattering

Im a software guy and just learning finances, but heres my take from what I know so far So from the tech side AI is definitely going to grow in applications and become a major technology. Everyone is trying to scale up to being able to use it, the chatbots and such available now are just toys. But from the software side everyone is trying to increase efficiency in being able to produce advanced AI. Right now it takes a ton of infrastructure and Nvidia is the only one capable of providing that. Others AMD will likely catch up eventually. And there are more competing trends more hardware right now directly corresponds to more advanced AI. Advances in the software space will decrease the hardware needed to get to advanced ai, but more available applications of AI will drive the need up at the same time. So from the finance side I know less about this, but it seems like a very volatile space. A lot of promise is probably creating a bubble effect. There are a lot of analogues to the dot com we know its gunna be big, but we dont understand how yet. A lot of companies are going to blow up on promise and then go under. I dont know how to make savvy decisions here yet, but what I am sure of is that I should watch it carefully but do anything very cautiously.

This explains it. Its a mix of technicals, but also recognizing when a strong downtrend ends and a mild uptrend begins. It hit the upper bollinger band, so the play was the bollinger rejection rather than it pushing widerhigher after the bearish reversal hammer candle. It was highly likely that itd make some sort of downward move over the coming week, perhaps testing the moving average once again, without any news flow. That moving average was around 450, so bets needed to be between the market price and that for maximum profit. Obviously DOJ news shifted that profit point in a major way.

About 15 years ago, I did some research on why large accounting software had zero sales in Asia, especially among SMBs. Here is what I found. Imagine going to a small manufacturing store to buy stuff. The owner keeps two virtual pots one in the front, the second in the back. The money and transactions get split between the two, getting pulled from either as needed when it comes to reporting. The inventory record itself gets split. Much of this is on a trust and deferred payment basis. Come tax time, only one of the pots gets declared. Also, even when there are chaintracking mechanisms like GST which are built on credits across the supply chain, there are plenty of TXNs where the credits dont apply. All those go to the second pot. Finally, when they have to get debt, they can artificially inflate the valuation by inflating orders through roundtripping by artificially increasing the second pot letting a subsidiary or fantom customer make those orders. It was crazy to see this whole thing in play in India and China at such a wide level. Not to say that Western companies dont do the same shit with IP relocation in tax shelters, but thats another story. Now scale that to SMCI, where they were once caught doing this and delisted, and have been accused again. That 8 of the orders came from their subsidiary, which hints at roundtripping or worse using that subsidiary to supply to Russia, etc. violating US federal laws That they pulled future revenues in the present quarter when payment was not made, and goods were not supplied to pad EPS and revenues, which went into the earnings report And other discrepancies... Their CEO claims no material changes because these are earnings after all, even though for another quarter. But both are illegal in the US, and if proven THEY WILL be punished. And I can understand why EY wont sign on any audit reports without validating that Txns from both pots occurred in the quarter they claimed they would, and earnings from the same period. If they were misreported internal controls are to be blamed, which is what the CEO claims are being reviewed. I think if they were clean 10K would have been a routine report. The fact that it has taken so much time implies bad news and legal trouble ahead. It would be foolish to touch SMCI at this point. There is a high likelihood they will get delisted and back as an OTC stock.

Or NVDA just funded a promising startup in the AI space 100 million to be precise, which needs lots of capital. Everything else is a nothing burger. The cost to build a large model now runs into billions of dollars. The cost to create server farms also is billions. So they have to raise capital. The fact that a startup can even do that, and compete with the likes of Google, Microsoft, and Amazon, is a pleasant surprise. But not a surprise given the demand right now.

The only negative impression I took from this is all this business should have been driven by Amazon, Microsoft, and Google as leading cloud providers. They are allowing startups like Coreweave to eat a big chunk of this pie. And it doesnt stop at GPU services alone. At some point, they will expand into storage and compute.

There are lots of new AI service over cloud providers in this space. Most of the business is for GPU services for AI model training, as related operations are very costly. If you look around, even data centers for bitcoin mining are branching into model training, as the GPU infra is essentially the same. Bitcoin being bitcoin, their cost fluctuates, and this allows them to target model training services when prices are down. The demand for these is insanely high right now. As we have seen in the past, most of them will eventually die or get bought by the big sharks. A handful of those who exist will be big and just coexist with Amazon and Microsoft offering their models and services on their cloud, or also on the big 3.

I dont believe any one strategy is better than another. Ill share my indicator stack and my favorite setups at the end but I first will share something I think is far more important Home Court Advantage I only trade in market conditions where I have home court advantage. Everyone trades better in certain market conditions and worse in others. But MOST people dont think about identifying which conditions theyre better in. So theyve been training to be professional snipers and dont realize theyre trading in a closerange gang shoot out. Dont be someone who trades every week of the year and expects the market to stay the same or youre good enough to consistently win in all conditions. Every successful professional trader I know specializes. Maybe its only day trading SPX first 3060 minutes of the day, or only trading one sector, or only trading when VIX gets above a certain level. So my main home court is preearnings season. About 1 month prior to the big tech earnings season. this means I only trade about 46 months a year. Sometimes I skip a season too. A perfect cadence for swing trading and tradelife balance. Why this season for me? I find that earnings are the only medium term, consistent event in stocks we can count on happening at a regular cadence. That is a very rare characteristic to have when operating in a random market. Nothing in the markets are predictable, except we KNOW earnings will bring about high volatility and attention. And the month leading up to that is always going from lower vol to higher vol conditions. This is the sweet spot Ive found myself performing best in Find your home court. My indicator stack is simple 20, 50, 200 SMA TTM Squeeze indicator Volume profile RSI MACD Again, I believe every indicator is just a tool and one is not better than another. Theyre just better for different conditions and trading styles Setups I like to enter trades during a time of sideways consolidation. This is identified by the Squeeze indicator. When a stock is squeezing sideways on multiple time frames, its even better. The longer the squeeze, the larger the subsequent move. The direction I take depends on my assessment of the trend and market conditions. During preearnings periods, its usually going long these days. Fallen Angels. Finding Stocks in a LTF downward trend that for some reason gap DOWN again in total capitulation. I then wait for these to go sideways for months, and everyone has dumped in total panic and despair. Theyve forgotten about it. And then wait for the SMAs and volume to give me a trigger to enter near the bottom and set a stop loss below the All time low. Also monitor if insiders begin to buy. short term, basic reversal trades at key resistance or support areas. For example if a stock or index hits its 50 month or 200 week moving averages with speed. Thats usually an easy put I can sell for a relatively quick win. Not buying calls, Id stick to selling puts for something like that Or another example would be shorting stocks in the same sector where several tickets are all hitting SMA resistances like AMD and NVDA did August 1st. These are MEANT to be base hits. Sometimes its a home run outta no where like my Aug 1st NVDA trade but normally I just expect like a 1020 gain Thats about it. Its pretty boring and simple with complexities due to my personal style. I mentor a few folks as a side gig nothing extravagant and usually when I try to teach them my style, it doesnt work. But it at least gives them a framework to work off of. Long term, Im just helping them get smaller, simpler, and more specialized in their trading. When you get more specialized, your volume of trades lowers but the quality of your trades sky rockets Best of luck!

The best advice I can give is to read Trading in the Zone. Best book that changed the trajectory of my trading. It helped me understand that the key to success in trading is ALL psychological. The secret to success in trading is not having a trading plans, being smarter or working harder. It is in getting to a mental maturity level where you can actually follow your trading plan, and where you know when to take yourself out of the game in order to protect your portfolio from yourself I have been trading for 14 years and I havent been consistently profitable until after the 10 year mark. Im maybe a little more intelligent now than I used to be. The biggest difference is my maturity now compared to before. I have learned to identify when Im not in the right mindset to trade well and make good decisions. I force myself to stop trading or lower my position sizes when Im too excited, confident, regretful, or sad about buying a dip that keeps dipping. And I can also tell when I am in a good mindset to make big conviction bets. These are all subtle things I had to learn about myself over 10,000 hours of failingmediocrityround tripping. Its not something I can teach you bc every human reacts to external stress and their emotions differently Im not saying we should be unemotional either. Thats a fallacy. We are humans and we cannot just stop feeling things. We can only control our actions and change our environment so that we are in the best mental state for success. TLDR Give the book a read. For conviction bets The main way is I take inventory of the things below 1. I did not have a big trade loss or profit in the last week or two. I gotta KNOW Im not revenge trading to make up a loss or cocky trading after a recent win. After about a week, Ive forgotten how much I made or loss and Ive calmed down 2. Ideally the last several trades I made were small or insignificant 3. If the setup which I want to take a big conviction bet on is one Ive been watching or keeping an eye out for a few weeks or months 4. I dont feel like I need to make this money trading exclusively out of retirement accounts basically locks this in for me 5. Im in a good place relationally with my wife These are things specific to me and I wouldnt say its necessary for anyone else. While it may seem unnecessarily cumbersome and silly, its what works for me. I do hear what if the perfect setup happens when youre in an argument? Youre just gonna skip it? Yes. I focus on the relationship bc thats what matters more. But this selfcreated rule maintains a balanced incentives system I wanna continue trading So minimize arguments In order to do that, I must learn to handle conflict better In doing that I must train myself to remain calm and controlled in my actions during times of stress and high emotions, With that training, I also improve my ability to control actions trading This usually leads to more profits

SEC's probes against EY were primarily due to two significant issues. First, EY faced charges for its audit professionals cheating on CPA ethics exams and misleading the SEC during the investigation by withholding evidence of this misconduct. Second, EY was charged with violating auditor independence rules by improperly soliciting confidential information from a client's Chief Accounting Officer during an audit pursuit, undermining their objectivity and impartiality. These actions resulted in significant penalties and highlighted failures in maintaining ethical standards and integrity.

E&Y in its letter says it does not disagree with the language of paragraph 7 of SMCI's statement released in the 8-K.  Paragraph 7 reads as follows:"Other than as described above, during the fiscal years ended June 30, 2024 and 2023, and the subsequent interim period preceding EYs resignation, (1) there were no disagreements, as defined in Item 304(a)(1)(iv) of Regulation S-K, with EY on any matter of accounting principles or practices, financial statement disclosure or auditing scope or procedure, which if not resolved to EYs satisfaction to our knowledge would have caused it to make reference to the subject matter thereof in connection with its report, and (2) there were no reportable events as described in Item 304(a)(1)(v) of Regulation S-K."This language seems to imply that the financial statements (i.e. the numbers) and related disclosures are not at issue. From all the disclosures so far, the issues appear to be: i) Governance, ii) Lack of transparency, iii) Completeness of communications to EY, iv) Internal control over financial reporting, v) Integrity and ethical values displayed by the management team, and vi) Ability and willingness of the Board to effectively oversee management/CEO.These concerns are pretty damning but fixable if the Board acts accordingly. If the financial statements (numbers) and disclosures are truely accurate, the Board should immediately address the CEOs/Management's related party shenanigans. The resignation of Ernst & Young (EY) as the auditor for Super Micro Computers has raised significant concerns about governance and transparency. EY cited their inability to rely on the companys management and audit committee, suggesting deeper issues in the companys financial reporting. Reports indicate that EY had previously flagged concerns regarding governance, transparency, and internal controls, warning that these deficiencies could jeopardize the accuracy of Supermicros financials.

The timing of EYs resignation, and the delayed public disclosure of it, has fueled speculation about potential insider activity. Some worry that employees at EY or Supermicro might have shared sensitive information about the resignation, possibly leading to insider trading before the announcement. Additionally, the late disclosure has frustrated shareholders, who feel blindsided by the news, particularly given the significant drop in Supermicros stock value. This situation opens the door to potential legal action, as shareholders could argue they were denied timely access to material information.

Critics also question whether EYs sudden exit was the best course of action. Many believe that, rather than resigning abruptly, the firm should have provided specific details on the financial issues they uncovered. Issuing a qualified opinion or alerting the market to specific concerns about overstatements in earnings could have offered more transparency and stability. While EYs resignation may protect the firm from liability, it has left investors with uncertainty about the true state of Supermicros finances and the potential consequences for the company, including a risk of delisting.

This incident casts doubt on the practices of both EY and Supermicro, with regulatory scrutiny likely to follow. Investigations may focus on whether there was insider trading or if either organization intentionally withheld critical information. The episode underscores the importance of timely and transparent communication in financial reporting and raises questions about accountability in the auditing process.

Company Impact:
 * Investor Confidence: The decline could erode investor confidence in the company's future prospects.
 * Funding Difficulties: It might become more challenging for the company to raise capital through equity offerings.
 * Merger and Acquisition Opportunities: The company could become a potential acquisition target for larger tech firms looking to expand their AI capabilities.
Investor Considerations:
 * Long-Term Perspective: Investors with a long-term perspective might view this as a buying opportunity, especially if the decline is due to temporary factors.

 * Fundamental Analysis: It's crucial to analyze the company's financials, growth prospects, and competitive landscape before making any investment decisions.
Important Note:
It's important to remember that stock prices can be influenced by various factors, including market sentiment, economic conditions, and company-specific news. Past performance is not indicative of future results.

Below, I summarize the key points from the Form 8-K filing by $SMCIOn October 24, 2024, Ernst & Young LLP (EY) resigned as Super Micros registered public accounting firm. EY was engaged in March 2023 to audit Super Micros fiscal year 2024 financial statements, but had not yet issued any reports.In late July 2024, EY communicated concerns to the Audit Committee about governance, transparency, and internal control issues at the company. In response, Super Micros Board appointed an independent special committee to review these matters.After receiving additional information through the review process, EY informed the special committee that it could no longer rely on representations from management and the Audit Committee. EY cited concerns about the companys commitment to integrity, the independence of the Audit Committee and Board, and its ability to rely on management representations.Super Micro disagrees with EYs decision to resign, stating the special committee investigation is still ongoing. However, the company is taking EYs concerns seriously and will consider the findings and recommendations of the special committee.Other than the issues raised by EY, there were no disagreements or reportable events between the company and EY during the fiscal years 2023 and 2024.Super Micro has begun identifying a successor independent registered public accounting firm.

If you are a new investor and you've heard the recent news about this company and you find yourself on this board reading all of the comments both for and against buying stock, please consider the following. A firm called Hindenberg investigated fraudulent actions committed by managers within the company and then opened up a position speculating that their report would cause the share price to fall. Hindenberg has been right and they have been wrong. Shortly after they released their findings, SMCI announced they were pushing back their earnings release, which is incredibly rare. Funds and investors announce short positions in companies all time, and the companies they're speculating about usually do not push back earnings because of it. Most recently, the independent firm that is responsible for auditing the books has resigned, forcing another push back for earnings. You'll read a lot of comments here telling you to buy as it is an amazing opportunity to make more money than you thought possible in a matter of days/weeks. Do what you want, but the comments pretending there's some "boogeyman" out there manipulating the share price of a $20bn company by 20+% is so absurd on its face it's laughable. If you want to risk some money on the chance that all of the unprecedented actions just taken by SMCI, disregard Hindenberg, aren't MAJOR red flags, be aware there's a pretty good chance you'll lose money. Good luck!

E&Y only agreed with first 3 sentences.  did not  agree with bolded sentences.      appears E&Y was not being completly updated on findings.In late July 2024, EY communicated to the Audit Committee concerns about several matters relating to governance, transparency and completeness of communications to EY, and other matters pertaining to the Companys internal control over financial reporting, and that the timely filing of the Companys annual report was at significant risk. From an AI search.....    When Hindenburg Research targets a company and releases a negative report, the company's stock price may decline. This is because Hindenburg and its limited partners take a short position in the company before the report is released. Short selling is a trading strategy where investors borrow shares of a stock and sell them, with the intention of buying them back later at a lower price. The difference between the selling and buying prices is the profit for the short seller

Losing NVIDIA (NVDA) as a customer would pose a significant risk to Super Micro Computer Inc. (SMCI) due to the crucial role NVIDIA plays in SMCI's business model, particularly in high-performance computing, artificial intelligence, and data centers. Here are the key risks associated with such a scenario:

1. Revenue Impact: NVIDIA GPUs are central to SMCI's servers and high-performance computing solutions. A loss of NVIDIA as a customer would mean SMCI might struggle to fulfill demands for GPU-intensive applications, impacting revenue, particularly in data centers and AI-driven projects.


2. Market Position and Competitiveness: SMCIs ability to remain competitive heavily depends on access to cutting-edge NVIDIA GPUs. Without them, SMCI may lose ground to competitors with NVIDIA-powered solutions, affecting its position in the high-performance computing and AI markets.


3. Product Development and Innovation: NVIDIAs GPUs are integral to SMCIs product roadmap, particularly for AI and machine learning applications. Losing access to NVIDIA products could hinder SMCIs ability to develop advanced servers optimized for these applications.


4. Customer Relationships and Perceptions: Customers may view NVIDIA-powered solutions as an industry standard, so losing NVIDIA could reduce customer interest in SMCIs offerings. It may also affect relationships with customers in markets where NVIDIAs brand holds significant influence.


5. Transition Costs: If SMCI loses NVIDIA, it might need to turn to alternative GPU suppliers (like AMD) or redesign products to accommodate different architectures, which could lead to increased R&D costs, slower product cycles, and potential compatibility issues.



While SMCI may diversify its suppliers or pursue strategic alternatives, the risk remains substantial, especially in the short to medium term, given NVIDIAs current market dominance in GPU technology.

This is my second experience with a Hindenburg research article about a company.  The first time with my first stock, I took the bait when the company said that the accusations were not true, etc.  I definitely lost money on that deal, but at least I got out before the stock hit the penny leven and it did a reverse split.  When the Hindenburg article came about about SMIC, again, I bought into what the company said about false or misleading claims.  Also, I kept thinking that SMIC had leading edge technology with their cooling racks. Supermicro doesn't see restatement of quarterly reports for FY24In a regulatory filing, Supermicro said the Chair of the Audit Committee discussed with Ernst & Young the reasons for EY's resignation. The company has begun the process of identifying a successor independent registered public accounting firm. The company will authorize EY to respond fully to the inquiries of the successor independent registered public accounting firm, once selected. The company does not currently expect that resolution of any of the matters raised by EY, or under consideration by the Special Committee will result in any restatements of its quarterly reports for the fiscal year 2024 ending June 30, 2024, or for prior fiscal years. EY was engaged on March 15, 2023 to perform an audit for the company's fiscal year ending June 30, 2024, and has not issued any report on the company's financial statements or the company's internal control over financial reporting. EY resigned while conducting the audit for the company's fiscal year ended June 30, 2024, EY's first audit on the company's behalf.

I am chartered Accountant and CPA. Let me share the weight of the problem.  Company's Revenue Recognition is inconsistent and misleading. Adopting of Costing is also not following matching principles.  These are not consistent with Generally Accepted Accounting  Principles =GAAP.  Further there are several guidelines issued by Financial Accounting Standandards Board- FASB.  An Auditor are required to attest any documents only if they follow these principles are guidelines. If not, they are required to ask for justification from management for any deviations/violations. if the ansyer is not adequate, they should issue a "qualified report".  A Qualified report is very damaging. Or they should not accept engagement and should refuse to sign.   This is exactly what happens.  Guess what.  Accounting Professional Standards requires incoming auditor to get a consent and explanation why they resigned. If the answer is convincing, then the new auditor should not accept engagement. Any violation of these professional guidelines will result in yanking the practice licence by AICPA. No auditor would want that.  So in a nutshell, SMCI has no choice except to correct themselves and follow the guidelines. They cannot throw tantrum. More they wait, they will be dinged. Next is SEC and DOJ will be ubering to SMCI soon. In the meantime, NVDA will publicly disconnect themselves from SMCI. Because they dont want to associate with violators. I am a retired CPA(inactive). I can not even begin to tell you how rare a move like this by an audit firm is. No one wants to walk away from a large company like this - I can not even imagine what E&Y billings were to a client this size and complexity. When you consider the fact that E&Y is one of the best accounting firms in the world: I would assume either management at SMCI was deliberately and willfully trying to mislead E&Y, or alternatively (and I think very possibly) the accounting simply got out of control as their growth exploded and it is so out of control, that management and staff truly don't know what is going on and put simply their accounting records are not accurate. Either way by the time you get a new auditor in and they get through everything they need to work through - you are looking at several months minimum and it could take a lot longer then that to get cleaned up. They are going to be very lucky if they avoid de-listing and even if they do, when they report their numbers may not resemble the numbers previously reported. I will also say, they will lose a lot of business because of this. Large companies and governments will avoid working with them if at all possible. This is a disaster for these guys. If you are long, you will be real lucky if this stock stays above $20.

CPA auditor here - I just read the 8 K filing and resignation letter from EY. Management does not expect any material restatements. No question EY does not want any sort of potential liability because the internal controls are likely very messy, which I have seen many times before. Management reiterates (under clear threat of imprisonment if they lie., or even if they unknowingly make a negligent statement), no material adjustments to the financial statements are expected. It will be interesting to see if there are any earnings announcements today They may be delayed yet again, as the company now has appoint a new external auditor. Please keep in mind external auditors perform two independent assessments, one relating to an audit of the financial statement, balances and footnote disclosures, and 2) an attestation of the design and operating effectiveness over internal controls related to financial reporting. it is altogether possible we could have a clean audit opinion on the financial statements, but not on internal controls over financial reporting. I suspect that is what is happening. I think it is unwise to emotionally buy or sell right now.

Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI) filed an extension for its 2024 Form 10-K annual report, and the new deadline is September 29, 2024. The company's original deadline was September 14, 2024, but they filed a Form 12b-25 extension on August 30, 2024. The delay was due to the company needing more time to assess its internal controls over financial reporting.If SMCI doesn't file the 10-K by the extended deadline, it could face complications like stock trading restrictions or a negative impact on investor confidence.The company received a non-compliance letter from Nasdaq for the delay. The letter states that SMCI has 60 days to regain compliance or submit a plan to do so. If the company submits and has its plan accepted, Nasdaq could grant it an extension of up to 180 days from the original due date. If Nasdaq doesn't accept the plan, SMCI can appeal to a Nasdaq hearings panel.

Here is the deal as I see it.  Last year they reported Q1 on November 1st.  What do you think the odds are of that happening this year?  When do you think they will get the June 30th year end work done?  Will there be any material changes?  How long will September 30th (Q1) be delayed due to issues with closing the year?  If and when they do finally report are we going to see margins continue to fall even though revenue is increasing?  The way I see it, there is only one announcement that will make the stock go up - they announce the YE and Q1 results, without any material financial errors, margins rebound in June and September from March levels.  If that happens - the stock goes much higher.  If they fail in any of these - if they continue to delay results, if they come out and say their will be a financial restatement, if they report and margins continue to fall; any of this and the stock will be back in the $20's or worse.  I bought puts late last week, because I think the odds strongly favor a bad announcement on one or more of these items soon.  As we go past November 1 - the odds of some type of announcement increases so whatever is going to happen should happen sometime between now and the end of November.

BlackRock did not sell SMCI stocks in 2024, but it did increase its ownership of the company:January 2024: BlackRock filed an SC 13G/A form with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) disclosing ownership of 6,381,749 shares of Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI). This represented 11.5% ownership of the company, an increase of 16.93% from the previous filing in January 2023.January 2023: BlackRock reported owning 5,457,942 shares of SMCI.BlackRock is one of the largest shareholders of SMCI, along with Vanguard Group Inc., Susquehanna International Group, Llp, State Street Corp, and others.

I don't think we will see a 10-Q next week.From my research:"No, a company generally cannot file a 10-Q if they have not filed the previous 10-K. The 10-K, which is the annual report, provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial condition, including audited financial statements. This forms the basis for the quarterly 10-Q reports, which are unaudited but offer an update on the company's financial performance.The SEC requires companies to be current in their filings. If a company has not filed the 10-K, it may be considered delinquent and could be subject to enforcement actions or trading restrictions. Companies often need to file both missing reports to regain compliance if they have fallen behind.However, in certain circumstances, companies may file a Notification of Late Filing (Form 12b-25) to request additional time for the 10-K filing, and the SEC may grant it, delaying subsequent filings like the 10-Q."

This question is getting asked a lot.

Publicly traded companies like Super Micro Computers (SMCI) must submit quarterly (10-Q) and annual (10-K) filings to the SEC. However, there is no legal requirement to file the 10-K before releasing earnings results. Companies often publish preliminary earnings or press releases ahead of the official filings to keep investors informed.

The 10-K serves as a detailed, comprehensive report with audited financials, management analysis, and disclosures. On the other hand, an earnings release typically provides key financial metrics like revenue and earnings per share, which are often unaudited.

As long as the company complies with Regulation Fair Disclosure which ensures that all material information is shared with the public at the same timethey are allowed to release earnings data before filing the 10-K. If the 10-K is delayed, the company may file a Form 12b-25 with the SEC to request an extension, but this delay does not prevent them from issuing a summary of their financial performance through an earnings release.

In practice, companies often release earnings first and follow up with the 10-K later, ensuring timely updates to investors while meeting their reporting obligations.

The Hindenburg short report was the icing on the cake, but the fact is that SMCI stock had already been cut in half (from highs) prior to that report. That report was the final 15-20% haircut.SMCI was on a roll and remember, the quarter prior to June 2024 (March 2024 quarter) SMCI had stopped the bleeding and actually grew GPM (Gross Profit Margin) a bit in that March 2024 quarter. That was the first time GPM had risen since the 09/22 quarter. Many on the street expected the margins to at least hold steady, and with the top line revenue number exploding, the stock took off.Unfortunately, GPM fell significantly in the June 2024 quarter, catching the street (and retail) by surprise.Below are the GPM numbers since 09/22 quarter.GPM Numbers:09/22  18.76%12/22  18.71%03/23  17.64%06/23  17.01%09/23 - 16.69%12/23  15.40%03/24 - 15.52%06/24 - 11.23%It isn't simply a "short" story (I couldn't resist the pun). The two catalysts that will begin to get SMCI going again are: 1) A clean 10-k to provide confidence in the financials being reported (eliminating  uncertainty and restoring trust); and, 2) improved margins (demonstrating improved operations and management).

Folks, the SMCI 10-K is due no later than November 16, 2024 (60 calendar days from the Nasdaq issued compliance letter). SMCI received the notification letter from Nasdaq stating that the Company is not in compliance with Nasdaq listing rule 5250(c)(1), which requires timely filing of reports with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. The September 17, 2024, Nasdaq letter was sent as a result of SMCIs delay in filing its Annual Report on Form 10-K for the period ending June 30, 2024 (the Form 10-K). The SMCI Form 10-K was due on August 29, 2024.SMCI has 60 days from the date of the notice (again, September 17, 2024) either to file the Form 10-K or to submit a plan to Nasdaq to regain compliance with Nasdaqs listing rules. If a plan is submitted and accepted, SMCI could be granted up to 180 days from the Form 10-Ks due date to regain compliance. If Nasdaq does not accept SMCIs plan, then SMCI will have the opportunity to appeal that decision to a Nasdaq hearings panel.So, no later than November 16, 2024, SMCI will either file the 10-K or submit a plan to Nasdaq to regain compliance  BOTH THESE OPTIONS WILL REQUIRE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE. As a result, we will know the status of the 10-K by November 16, 2024.

Super Micro Computer Inc. (SMCI) is currently viewed by many analysts as more attractive than Nvidia for some investors, primarily due to its lower valuation and strong growth prospects in AI hardware. While Nvidia remains the leader in AI chips, SMCI is a key player in the hardware market, particularly with its focus on providing high-performance servers for AI data centers.Unlike Nvidia, which is often seen as overvalued due to the significant price increase in recent years, SMCI has more room for growth. The stock appears relatively undervalued, while demand for its products increases due to the global AI expansion. This makes it an appealing option for investors looking to capitalize on the growth in the AI sector without paying Nvidia's high valuation

Supermicro's forward price-to-earnings multiple of 14.6 trades at a discount to the S&P 500 index average of 24. And this valuation looks too low for a business with a triple-digit annual growth rate. Shares could substantially outperform the wider market during the next three years and beyond.

TSMCs discovery raises questions about how Huawei, considered Chinas best hope of ascending the semiconductor industry, got its hands on advanced chips. Research firm TechInsights recently discovered that Huaweis latest AI servers contained processors made by TSMC, Nvidia Corp.s most important manufacturing partner.Huawei has been on a sanctions list since 2020 and is barred from doing business with TSMC and its chipmaking peers without a US government license. In the past year, Huawei has relied on local partner Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. for production, including a 7-nanometer chip unveiled last August in a Huawei smartphone.But US officials have questioned SMICs ability to make 7-nm chips at scale. Huaweis use of TSMC output for its latest AI chips may be a sign that reinforces that narrative. The Taiwanese chipmaker has said it stopped all shipments to Huawei after Sept. 15, 2020, which the company reiterated when asked about the TechInsights report.

TSMC halted shipments to the client around mid-October after it realized semiconductors fabricated for that entity had found their way into Huawei products, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said. The chipmaker has since notified the US and Taiwanese governments and is investigating the matter more thoroughly, the person said, asking not to be identified discussing a sensitive situation.Its unclear whether the TSMC client was acting on Huaweis behalf, or where its based. But the incident sheds new light on reports that surfaced in past days, including from The Information, that Washington reached out to TSMC recently about whether the company had produced chips for the blacklisted Chinese company.TSMCs discovery raises questions about how Huawei, considered Chinas best hope of ascending the semicondHuawei has been on a sanctions list since 2020 and is barred from doing business with TSMC and its chipmaking peers without a US government license. In the past year, Huawei has relied on local partner Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp. for production, including a 7-nanometer chip unveiled last August in a Huawei smartphone.But US officials have questioned SMICs ability to make 7-nm chips at scale. Huaweis use of TSMC output for its latest AI chips may be a sign that reinforces that narrative. The Taiwanese chipmaker has said it stopped all shipments to Huawei after Sept. 15, 2020, which the company reiterated when asked about the TechInsights report.

The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the US Department of Justice (DOJ) recently announced parallel actions against an activist short seller and his firm, charging them with multiple counts of securities fraud.1 The charges are the latest reminder of the prevalence of short sellers who seek to drive down the stock price of public companies by engaging in short-and-distort campaigns. DOJ & SEC Bring Enforcement Actions Against Short Sellers, Highlighting Continued Prevalence of Short Selling Against Public Companies .....The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the US Department of Justice (DOJ) recently announced parallel actions against an activist short seller and his firm, charging them with multiple counts of securities fraud.1 The charges are the latest reminder of the prevalence of short sellers who seek to drive down the stock price of public companies by engaging in short-and-distort campaigns. In these campaigns, short sellers sell a public companys stock short and then spread disparaging, false rumors about the company, attempting to profit from the stock price decrease caused by their misinformation.

There are several reasons why a company might not want to file a 10-K with the SEC, including:Omitting sensitive informationA company might not disclose sensitive information or might be defensive about disclosing it.Regulatory compliance issuesA company might have regulatory compliance issues or legal disputes that are not fully disclosed in the 10-K.Potential for negative market reactionIf a company files a 10-K late, the market might react negatively. Penalties for late filing include de-registration by the SEC, de-listing by stock exchanges, and the inability to raise capital through public securities.

Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) stock Super Micro Computer (SMCI) designs and manufactures high-performance servers and storage systems for artificial intelligence (AI) data centers. Over the past few years, SMCIs earnings have exploded as the AI arms race takes hold of Wall Street.Hindenburg Research Report Slams SMCIFrom January to March, SMCI shares quadrupled as the AI hype took over Wall Street. Since then, the stock has roundtripped those gains, and now Hindenburg Research, a short-selling firm, is coming after the company. In late August, Hindenburg Research accused SMCI of glaring accounting red flags. The next day, SMCI delayed its annual report filing (10K), sending shares plummeting. To Hindenburgs credit, the company has previously uncovered some fantastic short opportunities, like the EV maker Nikola.However, investors should take those results with a grain of salt for two reasons. First, Hindenburg takes a short position before announcing its claims to the public, providing Hindenburg with a clear incentive to bash the company. Second, though Hindenburgs short reports often lead to short-term weakness, they dont always spell the end of the road. For example, Hindenburg came after Adani Group, an Indian multinational company, in 2022. The bad press resulted in a market cap drop from $206 to ~$100 billion. However, by 2024, Adani had recovered its losses.

Algorithms and high-frequency trading can create the appearance of selling when the actual intent is to buy or cover short positions. One tactic, called spoofing, involves placing large sell orders that are canceled before execution to simulate selling pressure, which pushes prices down and allows traders to buy at lower levels. Layering works similarly by placing many small sell orders at different levels to create the illusion of resistance, then removing the orders once the price drops.

Another technique, known as painting the tape, involves rapid buying and selling of the same shares to make it appear that there is increased market activity. This can mislead other investors into thinking the stock is weak or under selling pressure, which drives further selling.

In stocks like SMCI, where short interest is high, these tactics can help short sellers cover their positions quietly without triggering upward pressure. However, with strong AI-driven demand and SMCIs fundamentals still in play, the stocks real value will likely emerge over time, potentially triggering a rally if the shorts get caught off guard.

As of the latest report, Super Micro Computer (SMCI) continues to experience intense short-selling activity. On September 30, 2024, short interest surged to 94.85 million shares, reflecting a 988 percent increase from the previous reporting period. With an average trading volume of around 76.88 million shares, the short interest ratio sits at 1.2 days to cover, meaning it would take that amount of time for all short positions to be closed based on typical daily trading volume.

The semiconductor sector, including SMCI, may experience volatility today due to Taiwan Semiconductors positive news potentially boosting the entire industry. Given the high short interest in SMCI, there is a chance of a short squeeze if investors react to the positive sentiment by covering their positions, leading to sharp price movements.
Super Micro Computer trades for 13.9 times forward earnings compared to theS&P 500, which trades at 23.5 times forward earnings, dirt cheap!

Smci management also expects its growth to continue for some time, because it believes it's on a path to $50 billion in annual revenue. It expects $26 billion to $30 billion for fiscal year 2025 (ending June 30, 2025), which is significant growth from 2024's $14.9 billion total.

I did the maximum pain computation for smci for the options expiring this Friday.  This shows that the best outcome for the options dealers will be if on Friday smci closes about at $46.00.  or $47.00.  In that case they will have to pay off about 66 million dollars to the holders of  in the money calls and puts.  This is less than they would owe for other outcomes. Just for interest if the stock is $50 on Friday, the options guys have to pay off 78 million.  If it closes at $44 on Friday the options guys have to pay off about 76 million, so $46 or $47 is where they have to pay off the least.  This is not fool proof, but the option sellers and the hedge funds and insurance companies who back them do have ways of moving the market a few points when necessary.  They may regard this as one of those times.

Super Micro Computer (SMCI) has displayed promising movement this week following its 10-for-1 stock split on October 1, 2024. After the split, the stock experienced a rally of around 20%, signaling a positive response from investors. This type of movement, often referred to as a relief rally, suggests renewed confidence in the stocks potential.

Currently, SMCI appears to be in a consolidation phase, where the stock price stabilizes around a range of $47 to $49. Consolidation is typically a healthy sign after significant price movement, as it allows traders to assess the new levels. This pattern can precede further upward momentum, which aligns with the generally bullish sentiment seen this week.

With earnings scheduled for November 6, 2024, some volatility might emerge as the market reacts to new financial information. If you believe in SMCIs growth prospects, especially given its position in the AI and server infrastructure sectors, now could be a reasonable entry point. However, given the upcoming earnings, it may also be wise to monitor the stock closely or wait until after the report to see how the market responds.

Some people cant see the forest for the trees. Anyone betting against Super Micro Computer (SMCI), is in reality, also betting against the likes of NVIDIA, AMD, Intel, and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC). If SMCI runs into significant issueswhether its from the short seller report or the Department of Justice investigationthose problems could have a massive ripple effect across the chip sector. SMCI plays a crucial role in providing high-performance servers that power AI, data centers, and cloud computing, all of which rely heavily on chips from these major companies. If SMCI cant produce servers, it would directly affect the demand for NVIDIA and AMDs GPUs, Intels CPUs, and TSMCs chips. This could slow the growth in the AI and data center sectors, which are major revenue drivers for these companies. A disruption like that wouldnt just hurt SMCI, it would hit the entire semiconductor market, causing a sell-off as investors reassess growth prospects. Essentially, betting against SMCI is indirectly betting against the future growth of the chip industry, and that could have wider consequences than people realize.

The recent activity in Super Micro Computer (SMCI) shows a mix of signals for retail investors. On one hand, the Three Inside Up candlestick pattern suggests a potential bullish reversal, indicating that the stock may be poised for a rebound as selling pressure weakens. However, the options market tells a different story, with a significant volume of put options being traded. This suggests that while some investors may be bullish in the long term, they are hedging against short-term risks by using puts.

The most likely explanation is that many long-term investors are using puts to protect their positions from short-term volatility. This is a common strategy to manage risk while maintaining a bullish outlook for the future. For retail investors, this suggests that while there is optimism for long-term growth, caution should be exercised in the short term due to the possibility of continued volatility.

Depending on your risk tolerance, holding your position or adding to it could make sense, but be mindful of short-term fluctuations and consider protective strategies if necessary.

Based on the recent candlestick analysis of SMCI (Super Micro Computer), the stock appears to show signs of bullish momentum. In the short term, patterns such as Bullish Engulfing and Three Inside Up were observed, which are generally strong indicators of upward movement. These patterns suggest that buyers are stepping in, potentially reversing any recent downward trends.

Additionally, there has been a Bullish Doji Star in the weekly timeframe, another pattern indicating a possible reversal or upward shift in the near future. However, its important to note that while bullish signals are emerging, SMCI still exhibits high volatility, so monitoring volume and broader market conditions will be key for short-term movements

If youre planning to trade based on these signals, make sure to confirm with other technical indicators and broader market trends, as these patterns suggest potential upward movement but dont guarantee it.

Professionals typically avoid shorting stocks with extremely high volatility, like SMCIs 98%, because unpredictable price swings can lead to substantial losses. While some might use strategies like hedging to manage risk, high volatility creates too much uncertainty, increasing the risk of a short squeeze. The time to have shorted SMCI would have been when it was trading at much higher levels, before the recent drop. Now, much of the downside potential is likely priced in, and shorting it after such a decline is riskier due to the increased chance of a rebound.

Chris, listen for a change.

"based on the work done so far, we dont anticipate any material changes in our fourth quarter or fiscal year 2024 financial results.".  If circumstances change in a material way (i.e., if the changes are significant enough to impact the company's financial performance), the speakeror the companymay be legally required to update stakeholders to avoid legal issues. This requirement comes from the obligations that companies have under securities laws and financial regulations, which generally require:Timely Disclosure: Publicly traded companies must provide updated information to investors, particularly if new information comes to light that could significantly affect the companys stock price or financial performance. Failure to disclose such material changes could lead to legal consequences, including investor lawsuits or regulatory penalties.Duty to Update: While not every change requires a formal update, if the company had previously issued guidance (like the statement you've referenced), and then material facts change that make that guidance inaccurate, there could be a duty to update that guidance. This helps ensure investors are not misled by old or outdated information.Avoiding Legal Liability: If the company knew or should have known that the previous statement was no longer accurate, failing to provide an update could be seen as misleading. This could open the door to legal action, especially if investor suffer losses due to relying on outdated information.

Cap expenditures increased and margins fell naturally, but SMCI should be ready to fill huge orders in their new factories. Expect margins to improve once the revenue flows in to offset

Super Micro Computer finished the fiscal year 2024 with a sizable reduction in its margins. And while that would usually be interpreted negatively by investors, it makes perfect sense for the company. In 2024, gross margins shrink to 14.2% from 18.1% in fiscal 2023. The main driver is increasing production of its server solutions to deploy AI graphics processing units (GPUs)  like those produced by tech behemoths NVIDIA Corp. (NASDAQ: NVDA) and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (NASDAQ: AMD). As a result, the company is positioning itself for growth alongside increased demand for GPUs, which ultimately will cause NVIDIA and Advanced Micro Devices successes to trickle down to Super Micro Computer. Most recently, 70% of SMCIs revenue was from sales of its GPU server solutions for AI implementation. The market for direct liquid cooling (DLC) servers  which Super Micro Computer provides  is expected to grow from $5 billion in 2024 to $21 billion in 2029.

My take, if your company is not prepared for this pace of growth it can actually be a bad thing. Dont get me wrong its a great problem to have but things like where are all the orders going, the authorization of discount levels, rev recognition, the inventory levels to support the pace of business are all in flux when youre frantically trying to fulfill orders. They are not a Dell, HP or IBM who have been fulfilling these enterprise orders at this pace for decades. They got caught behind the 8 ball with some of these internal processes and regulation and lost oversight on the business. They got called out by Hindenburg and are being extra extra cautious about accounting irregularities given their past. Now they are reviewing everything, I mean everything on the money side of the business so they are crystal clean going forward. They will post their 10K soon. One key tip for succeeding in binary options trading is to implement effective risk management. It's essential to set clear and realistic financial goals, decide how much capital you're willing to risk on each trade, and maintain a consistent risk-reward ratio. By limiting your risk to a small percentage of your overall trading capital, you can safeguard against significant losses and ensure you have enough funds to continue trading.

Avoid emotional decision-making and adhere to your trading plan, even during market fluctuations. Additionally, staying educated about market trends, economic indicators, and global events will enable you to make more informed trading choices. Keeping up with market news and analysis can provide an edge and help you spot potential profitable opportunities.

Finally, regularly evaluate and refine your trading strategy. By reviewing past trades to understand what worked and what didnt, you can adjust your approach to enhance your skills and boost your chances of success in binary options trading. By practicing effective risk management, staying informed, and continually refining your strategy, you can thrive in binary options trading and achieve long-term success.

Wow, SCMI not only build new data centers, but also modernize existing ones.  The market is huge.  Here is why: If you are building new ones, you will need a piece of land to build it.  When you source this land, you will know the size of the land you need based on the computer power you need.  So that is simple.  But when it is old data center, you size is pretty much fixed.  Lot of the old data centers are in a building, say, in the basement, which can not be possibly expanded in size.  So you basically needs to put a lot of new computing power in the same space you obtained 20 years ago.   What you have to do? You increase density, and the only possible way for you to increase density is to have liquid cooling.  lol.Taiwan produces the most savvy engineers who possesses keen vision on what the world needs in computing in the future years. Note from Scout Investments:Super Micro Computer, Inc. (NASDAQ:SMCI) was the top detractor to returns in the second quarter. Super Micro designs and manufacturers server solutions based on modular and open-standard architecture. This modular approach combined with a strong engineering culture helps the company to supply the market with advanced servers and rack-scale compute solutions quickly. After an impressive return in the first quarter, the company offered disappointing near-term earnings guidance, though we do not believe its long-term opportunity has diminished. We expect continued strong growth for several years, although the range of outcomes is quite wide; it is difficult to forecast AI server market growth with precision.

The thing that gets me the most and is the most outrageous of all the Hindenburg claims, is that theyare selling their AI servers to enemy countries like Russia and Iran. This is a total lie. The Wall Street Journal alreadyreported that they found servers from both DELL and HP in China and the DOJ warned both of them. The bottom line is, if a technology company has their technology show up in a restricted country, it certainly does not mean that that company was sellingtheir products to these countries. Once sold and out in the field, the technology black market uses devious means to get their products into countries like North Korea, Russia and China. Investors - please note this fact.

The DOJ has only agreed to contact and listen to people familiar with SMCI accusations (per the Wall Street Journal). There is no big in-depth investigation because right now it's simply a matter of one person making unsubstantiated claims...

Companies don't call Nvidia when you need AI - you call an AI server company like SMCI. They assemble the GPU chips, the power supply, the memory, software and networking - then test everything and ship. They provide the all-important Direct Liquid Cooling for the Blackwell chips, which draw huge amounts of power and run hot, so anyone providing DLC in their server has a big advantage.

We have been here before and look where we have come.  Around two years ago, in October 2022, Spruce Point Capital Management, a prominent short-seller, released a critical report about Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI). The report raised concerns about the companys accounting practices and alleged mismanagement. Nothing came of this report.  As a result, SMCIs stock price dropped significantly, falling to around $32 per share...that would be $3.20 after the split.  This negative assessment led to a major short-selling wave like now, influencing market perception of SMCI during that period.  But it rebounded quickly and now AI is dominating the markets.

Found it!"The September 17, 2024 letter was sent (from Nasdaq) as a result of the Companys delay in filing its Annual Report on Form 10-K for the period ending June 30, 2024 (the Form 10-K). The Form 10-K was due on August 29, 2024. The Company filed a Form 12b-25 on August 30, 2024. The Nasdaq notice has no immediate effect on the listing or trading of the Companys common stock on the Nasdaq Global Select Market. Under the Nasdaq rules, the Company has 60 days from the date of the notice either to file the Form 10-K or to submit a plan to Nasdaq to regain compliance with Nasdaqs listing rules. If a plan is submitted and accepted, the Company could be granted up to 180 days from the Form 10-Ks due date to regain compliance. If Nasdaq does not accept the Companys plan, then the Company will have the opportunity to appeal that decision to a Nasdaq hearings panel."I'm guessing around October 29.

So, an SMCI investorin a 24% tax bracket selling his stock would be taxed $2,400 instead of$1,500 for his $10,000 capital gain.But Harris/Biden also don't like Trump's 2017 tax cuts, so letting themexpire next year would turn a 24% marginal tax bracket into a 28% taxbracket and the stock sale would be taxed $2,800. That would almostDOUBLE it! Mr. Trump likes the LT gain tax right where it is at 15%.Harris/Biden have also stated that the top corporate tax rate (the one thataffects SMCI the most) should be increased from 21% currently to 28%, anincrease of 33% on this company that would certainly hurt it's performanceand stock price.Mr. Trump wants to reduce the corporate rate from 21% to 15%. Like the LTgain tax proposals, Harris wants the rate almost DOUBLE what Mr. Trumpwants it to be.Harris also wants to tax un-realized gains for higher income investors. Companies are investing heavily in AI infrastructure to meet the growing demands of machine learning, data processing, and AI-driven applications. This spending is largely concentrated on building data centers, acquiring specialized hardware, and optimizing cloud infrastructure. According to a report by McKinsey, global AI infrastructure spending could reach up to $500 billion by 2027, highlighting the critical role it plays in the future of AI development. A large part of this investment is focused on AI-specific hardware like Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) and Application-Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICs), which are crucial for training and deploying AI models. NVIDIA, a dominant player in AI chips, has seen demand for its GPUs soar, largely due to their centrality in deep learning tasks. Jensen Huang, the CEO of the firm, has remarked that the AI boom is underpinned by massive infrastructure needs, and the market is just at the beginning of this growth curve.

People with high emotions rarely succeed in the stock market because emotions often drive poor decisions. Fear leads to panic-selling during downturns, and greed drives buying during bubbles, which results in buying high and selling low. The markets volatility makes emotional reactions even more harmful, leading to overtrading and unnecessary losses. Successful investors rely on discipline, long-term strategies, and fundamental analysis, avoiding the pitfalls of short-term emotional swings. Keeping emotions in check is crucial for steady gains over time

NASDQSpecfor my long-trader friends. Posted Sept.28 Another Stock Market Power Trend has occurred. There are four discernableand definite criteria that identify an indices POWER TREND. Given the company's strong position in the AI market, Jablonski believes that once these allegations are resolved, "the stock goes back into its meteoric rise."

"Yes, there is some risk in the short-term that there's some volatility and some additional pullback, but I don't think that this company is necessarily going away. What they do is critical to the AI infrastructure, valuations or not. I think it's a company that is going to continue to skyrocket just because of the product that they deliver. Now, given this regulatory overhang we need to see what the result is," she tells Yahoo Finance.

This reminds me of the time my father had taken me to the store and let me pick out my favorite toy. I happily carried that toy around the store while he gathered the items we needed for home. As we walked, I would play and have fun with my new toy. We got to the counter to pay the cashier, and he gladly paid for everything and handed me back my toy without it being bagged. On the ride home he would be listening to the Beatles and smoking a cigarette while paying attention and humming along. Then out of nowhere he asked if he could see my toy, so I handed it to him. He asked me if I really liked it and I said, yes Dad, I Love it so much. He then threw my toy out the window. He said, I bet you didn't see that coming.... Then he told me the toy I had picked out was a symbol of his investments he made in Enron... That he too felt as empty as me I watched my toy get run over by every car behind us while looking through the back glass..... ahhh lessons taught to me by my father will always be such sweet memories

This is not an accounting problem. Its a long story. In fact, it is employees problem. Remember to keep your employees happy. SuperMicro Computer fired an employee. That ex-employee sued SMCI. Super Micro Computer, Inc. has filed lawsuits against former employees with millions of dollars. Super Micro Computer, Inc. has filed lawsuits against former employees. Proof Will Make Your $ Go PoofYou read lots about "Proof" on this board.  These comments confuse the law with how markets behave.In order to send people to jail they need proof - this is true.  Look at the history of Chainsaw Al Dunlap and Sunbeam as a great example of what happens when you ship bricks.  The stock started tanking before there was "proof".  I was short this name.Look at the history of Mike Pearson and Valeant Pharma. This is another great example of channel stuffing.  I was not short, but I sold as soon as a certain board member left.These companies were caught channel stuffing and the stock went down the tubes wiping our investors.But nobody needs proof to sell a stock, and most serious investors will not wait for proof either.Longs that wait for "proof" are going to lose money as many alread have in SMCI already.What the WSJ report says is that DOJ is asking people if they have information and that there is a current (not old) whistle blower lawsuit. No one should be surprised that a filing has not occurred by now you must remember a public company requires an independent board of directors within the board is an audit committee. The committee is independent. This committee announced , after the Hindenburg report,  that they required a full audit review of the financials before approving the 10k. This an exhaustive process of reviewing numbers, inventory, interviews including clients , deliveries compared to receipts and the list goes on. The management of SMCI have zero control over this process. Since the company and audit committee have restructured the CFO department since the last problem. It is very unlikely any material issues would be found. Also, the thought that the Biden administrations regulatory agencies would not launch a review during the election period is also delusional. This will be a long story with rumors and innuendo for months. Next week is the split, so hedge funds will have a more difficult time causing large swings and volatility in the stock. I believe the stock becomes very boring after the split and very little information will come from the audit.

Anybody who has not read WSJ article (and owns this stock) should read it.The allegation is very simple.The article says that there is a "whistle blower" who is a former employee of SMCI. This whistle blower says that the company knowingly shipped incomplete systems and improperly took such sales into revenue. Whistle Blowers are protected by law and anybody can go to the SEC site and look up this law.If (note I am saying if) SMCI did this, then this is a very clear case of accounting fraud and is commonly called "shipping bricks".The company was charged with similar charges in the past and paid a fine and the CEO also had to pay a $2.1M clawback due to Sarb Ox rules.According to the WSJ article there is an ongoing law suit and there was a hearing today during this which SMCI was attempting to force the whistle blower to go to arbitration.If you own this stock carefully read the WSJ article.I have been asking this board why they have 90 days of finished good invtory on the balance sheet. This a huge amount of inventory. Could it be that inventory is mis classified as finished goods when it is actually WIP??? This would explain why is so large... and would also be fraud.If this is true (and I am saying IF) this explains why the 10K is late and why E&Y will not sign off.If it is true then the revenues and other line items will have to be re-stated lower.You can not say you were not warned.
