This post is for all the clueless SMCI cheerleader clowns out there that have claimed NVDA books their sales the same way as SMCI is alleged to have booked sales where they will not deliver the product to the customer until a future quarter, but have booked the sale as earned on their P&L in the current reporting period. These clowns have claimed NVDA books such sales this way. Newsflash kids: No They DO NOT!NVDA and all other legit companies that follow GAAP rules (hint: not SMCI) properly book such transactions as deferred (unearned revenue) under the ASC 606 revenue recognition rules. Whether the customer pays you up front in cash, makes a deposit, or owes you receivables is wholly irrelevant to the booking of EARNED revenue under GAAP. You have to have actually fulfilled the performance obligations of the contract to legally book EARNED revenue on your P&L under ASC 606. NVDA books sales to be fulfilled in future periods as Unearned Revenue, which sits on their balance sheet as a liability, not a sale on the current period P&L.And if you do not understand this basic revenue recognition concept you really should NOT be investing in the stock market, but would be better off hiding your cash under your mattress.

The Nasdaq notice has no immediate effect on the listing or trading of the Companys common stock on the Nasdaq Global Select Market. Under the Nasdaq rules, the Company has 60 days from the date of the notice either to file the Form 10-K or to submit a plan to Nasdaq to regain compliance with Nasdaqs listing rules. If a plan is submitted and accepted, the Company could be granted up to 180 days from the Form 10-Ks due date to regain compliance. If Nasdaq does not accept the Companys plan, then the Company will have the opportunity to appeal that decision to a Nasdaq hearings panel.

For unsuspecting retail investors who need a bit of understanding of what has transpired with the delinquent 10k filing.SMCI had an opportunity to file a partial 10k or a fully audited 10k as of September 16, 2024. The full audit or partial audit of the 10k NEEDED to be signed off on by their current auditor which is EY.The current delinquent status and refusal of EY to sign off on, at minimum, the partial 10k raises serious questions as to the internal audit committee at SMCI.SMCI is now in breech of their debt covenants which is a very serious issue. SMCi CANNOT tap the equity markets for 12 months due to their 10k delinquency. Just the fact we are discussing this 10k issue sends shivers down the spines of investors of any security in delinquency status let alone a company that has been indicted for accounting fraud in the recent past. EY has been shedding clients (83) since January 2023 due to lack of internal Audit committees in these companies. EY doesnt need SMCI business that has the ability to further tarnish their credibility. EY will drop SMCI as a client due to the allegations from HI. SMCI has a regulatory duty to file an 8K detailing exactly why SMCI did not file the 10k OR PARTIAL by the deadline last week. They are a week late of this 8k and isnt an optional filing. This 8K NEEDS to be signed by their current auditor. TAKE HEED

With EYs ongoing efforts to revamp its audit practice, the firm has placed a strong emphasis on quality over quantity, even at the expense of losing market share. As the firm continues to navigate a challenging regulatory landscape, the leadership under Janet Truncale is focused on long-term improvements and adapting to the evolving demands of the audit industry. The question remains whether these efforts will be sufficient to restore EYs reputation and market position amid increasing competition from its Big Four peers.

The reduction in clients comes after the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) found that EYs rate of audit deficiencies had soared, prompting the firm to resign from certain public-company audits and limit new clients. The PCAOB reported that EY had the highest deficiency rate among the Big Four, with 46% of its 2021 audits showing significant shortfalls. In response, EY has undertaken a major overhaul of its U.S. audit practice, including the standardization of its approach, the building of centralized audit support teams, and a $1 billion investment in AI-enabled audit and tax platforms over the next three years. Despite these efforts, recent PCAOB inspections still found EY with the highest deficiency rate, though it had improved to 37%.

Ernst & Young (EY) is cutting ties with a significant number of U.S. public companies as audit clients in an effort to revamp its audit practice and improve the quality of its work. Between January 1, 2023, and August 15, 2024, 84 public companies exited EY as audit clients, with the firm adding only 21 new clients in the same period. This net loss of 63 clients starkly contrasts with its Big Four peersDeloitte, KPMG, and PwCwho all saw net gains in their client bases during this time. EY's move, which resulted in a loss of approximately $215 million in audit fees, is part of a broader strategy to enhance audit quality and respond to increasing scrutiny from regulators.

What is the benefit of filing the Form 12b-25?If the conditions of the Rule are met, filing the Form 12b-25 gives the issuer 15 additional calendar days to file a late annual report and five additional calendar days to file a late quarterly report. Moreover, if the report (or the incomplete portion) is actually filed within the 15-day or five-day grace period, the report is deemed to have been timely filed.

Folks, SMCI was never going to meet the 15-day grace period deadline to file their 10-K. Had that been their intention, they would have checked the box in their August 30th filing (FORM 12b-25) indicating they intended to meet the 15-day grace period deadline. As a result, SMCI accepted that SEC fines and capital raise limitations would/could be in play.The good news is that in the same filing (Form 12b-25) they did indicate (in checking the appropriate box) that they anticipate no significant change in results of operations from the corresponding period. They also reiterated this again in their subsequent 8-K filing on September 3rd.

So after more research, a Form 12b-25, also known as Form NT, is a document that companies file with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) when they are unable to file their 10-K or 10-Q on time. The form is also used to report other reasons why a company was unable to file on time, such as if the report could not be filed without unreasonable effort or expense. Hence these are the same document and gives a company 15 days extension.  So SMCI should have reported by Sept 15th.  Sorry about the previous wrong information.

Q.If I could not file my report on time becausethe Companysauditor could not completeits review, do I need to provide a letter from my auditor?A. Yes. Paragraph (c) of Rule 12b-25 requires the Companyto attach to the Form 12b-25 a statement signed by your audtior stating the specific reasons why it was unable to furnish the required opinion, report or certification on time.The regulators NEED to act against any company making a mockery of our capitalist system...There are rules and SMCI has proven they choose to not follow them

A company that fails to file a Form 10-K on time can face a number of consequences, including:   

Delisting: The company may be delisted from stock exchanges. 
 
Temporary trading suspensions: The company may face a temporary suspension of 10 trading days.

And

If a company is unable to file a periodic report on time, it must file a Form 12b-25 Notification of Late Filing. This form discloses the reason for the delay and indicates that the report will be filed within a specified time period.

This is how AI interprets 10-K delay with combination of lack of communication:More Serious Internal Issues: The lack of updates, particularly when a delay has already been announced, can be worrisome. When management is silent, it often indicates the internal review may have uncovered more complex or sensitive issues, which require additional time to resolve.Extended Audit Process: The delay might suggest the audit committee and external auditors are taking extra precautions to ensure everything is thoroughly reviewed. This could prolong the delay, especially if the company wants to avoid filing incorrect or incomplete information.Reputational Risk: The longer the delay continues without clear communication, the greater the risk to investor confidence. Transparency is crucial in maintaining trust, and the lack of updates since September 3rd could signal that management is navigating a more difficult situation than initially anticipated.And another question, how Much more delay can be expected?Typical Filing Extensions: Companies that miss filing deadlines due to internal reviews often take several weeks or even months to resolve issues, especially if external auditors are involved. Given that it has already been delayed for over 15 days, there is a possibility of another month or more before the filing is complete, depending on the complexity of the issues uncovered.Great. Typically, public companies switch auditors either to pay lower fees or because they have gone private, been acquired or outgrown the capabilities of the original firm. Audit firms also can drop clients, potentially if they have become overly risky or serving them presents a conflict of interest. Companies must disclose if they dismissed their auditor or their auditor resigned, though they dont have to provide additional detail that in some cases would further clarify the circumstances.

The move came after the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board found the rate of EYs auditing deficiencies, based on a sampling of audits of 2021 financial statements, surged to 46% from 21% in the previous year. It was the highest deficiency rate among the Big Four in the U.S.

There was  already a negative market response to NT filings in which management declared the filing will occur beyond the grace period (after 15 days). My advice to any new investors is invest 25% of what you are prepared to invest in any given stock. If it goes up, then you will make money. If it drops, you have the opportunity to average down. This has paid off for me. The mistake I have seen for many investors is that they panic when it drops and start averaging down when the share price moves against them by $5-10. If you are to average down, make sure its a meaningful average down, ie $50-100 movement. 

For existing investors, be patient and if you can meaningfully bring down your average consider it but prepare to hold for a period. If it goes up overnight, then happy days but if not then remember why you invested in the stock and be prepared to wait.

From the business point i am a bull, but lack of communication is what makes it increasingly uncomfortable. From this point on we have more-or-less two paths:A reasonable delay would be up to 2 weeks beyond the 15-day extension, provided SMCI continues to communicate progress -- If the company continues to provide transparent updates about the progress of the internal review, stakeholders will be more tolerant of a delay. Ongoing communication reassures investors that the delay is due to diligence rather than larger issues,Delays beyond 30-45 days without any filing or communication would likely be seen as excessive and could lead to significant investor concern and potential regulatory action. -- At that point, investors might start to worry that the internal review has uncovered deeper issues related to financial reporting or internal controls. The SEC may also view this kind of extended delay as problematic, especially if SMCI doesnt provide updates. If the delay drags on for several months, it could result in additional regulatory scrutiny, and the company could face consequences like stock exchange delisting warnings.Currently we are it the first part of reasonable delay, but we investors urgently need some communication of the progress.To put it differently: the delay is still within an acceptable range, but emphasizes the need for transparency from SMCI to maintain investor confidence.

The complaint filed alleges that, throughout the Class Period, Defendants failed to disclose to investors that: (1) the Company was subject to consistent overreporting of sales and underreporting of expenses; (2) it had re-hired multiple executives who departed in the wake of the Company's prior accounting scandal; (3) the Company has a closer relationship to its related parties than disclosed; (4) the Company had more related parties than it had disclosed; (5) the Company had not ceased exporting products to areas restricted by the United States government as a result of the Russia-Ukraine war, risking government sanction; and (6) as a result, Defendants' positive statements about the Company's business, operations, and prospects were materially misleading and/or lacked a reasonable basis at all relevant times.

The investment bank Mizuho Securities began monitoring Super Micro Computer (NASDAQ:SMCI) shares on Monday. The company received a "Neutral" ratingAlthough Super Micro Computer is considered a leading player in the AI server market, the company is facing significant challenges. These include loss of market share, pressure on profit margins, negative free cash flow and difficulties in internal control processes, reflected in delays in filing the 10-K report, among others. These factors have led to the "Neutral" rating despite the company's strong positioning in a growth market.In comparison, Mizuho sees Dell Technologies (NYSE:DELL) in a more favorable position. Dell's diversified portfolio, which includes servers, PCs and storage solutions, is emphasized as a strength. In addition, Dell scores with a stronger balance sheet, positive free cash flow and effective working capital management. Based on these factors, Dell receives an "Outperform" rating with a price target of USD 135.

Yes. A company is required to file a Form 12b-25 to provide notice of a late periodic report filing, regardless of whether it will be able to avail itself of the Rule 12b-25(b) extension period. If an issuer believes that it will not be able to file the periodic report within the extension period, it should not check the box in Part II of Form 12b-25 indicating that it will do so. In the event that the issuer does, in fact, file its periodic report within the Rule 12b-25(b) extension period and the periodic report includes all required disclosures, then the periodic report will be considered timely, even though the issuer did not check the box in Part II of Form 12b-25

Based on the information provided, Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI) was unable to file its Annual Report on Form 10-K for the period ending June 30, 2024, by the original deadline. However, they have stated in the filing that the Form 10-K will be submitted within the 15-day extension period allowed under Rule 12b-25(b). 

Since the original deadline for the Form 10-K would typically be 60 days after the end of the fiscal year (which in this case would be August 29, 2024), SMCI should file their 10-K on or before **September 13, 2024**, which is 15 days after the original deadline. But today is 16th

When a company fails to file its Form 10-K within the required 15-day extension period, it faces several potential consequences:Regulatory Penalties: The SEC may impose fines or other sanctions on the company. These penalties can vary based on the severity and duration of the non-compliance.Delisting Risk: The company might be at risk of being delisted from stock exchanges like the NYSE or NASDAQ. These exchanges have strict listing requirements, and failure to file required reports can lead to delisting.Legal Consequences: Shareholders or other stakeholders might take legal action against the company for failing to meet its reporting obligations. This could lead to lawsuits and further financial and reputational damage.

There was  a negative market response to NT filings in which management declares the filing will occur beyond the grace period (15-days) However, there may not be a negative market response to NT filings in which management declares the filing will occur within the grace period. Because the SEC considers these filings (15 days) to be timely, they impose no obvious costs on shareholders and hence may generate no market response.

Therefore, when they announced they will be delayed filing, there was a negative market response.  When they filed NT-10K, they already mentioned it as well as in the CEOs letter Thus, it was already priced in.

There was  a negative market response to NT filings in which management declares the filing will occur beyond the grace period (after 15-days) . However, there may not be a negative market response to NT filings in which management declares the filing will occur within the grace period (within 15 days) . Because the SEC considers these filings (within 15 days) to be timely, they impose no obvious costs on shareholders and hence may generate no market response.

Therefore, when SMCI announced they will be delayed filing, there was a negative market response. When they filed NT-10K, they already mentioned the delay as well as in the CEOs letter. NT 10-K delayed filing was already priced in.

There are a couple of interesting academic papers which are easy to read/understand concerning late filing.  Bertov and Kinchitchki "SEC Filings, Regulatory Deadlines and Capital Market Consequences" 2017 These authors are professors at UC Berkley and NYUS&P Capital IQ "Late to File The Costs of Delayed 10Q and 10K Company Filings" 2015So late filing is a well studied well document aspect of the capital markets, and it is very clear that it has long term consquences.The Bertov and Kinchitchki paper has an interesting comment in the abstract:"It also shows that investors do not accept management's delay-related assertions at face value, and that delayed filings signal continued poor performance..."Of course the liars in management and on this board will tell everybody how normal this all is and that it is a simple i dotting and t crossing exercise.  In the case of SMCI they will reference obviously fraudulent/fake chinese press articles to list excuses for managment's lack of ability to file.This is not a simple i dotting and t crossing exercise and this company needs to file their 10K.

People posting the deadline of filing 10K really need to learn how to do research here. After I only use 5 mins to do additional research, it seems there are different dates on 10K filing depending on the type of "filer". There are 3 different types of filer, for the fiscal period year end "June 30, 2024", here is the deadline to file 10K (Include the 15 day extension granted after filing an NT 10-K) :Non - Accelerated Filer : Due: Tuesday, October 15, 2024Accelerated Filer : Due: Monday, September 30, 2024Large Accelerated Filer : Due: Friday, September 13, 2024A large accelerated filer is simply an accelerated filer whose public float exceeds $700 million. Investors shouldn't be down on Supermicro stock because of the recent short report, but they also shouldn't be terribly excited about a stock split, either. Although business has been booming with Supermicro's sales doubling in recent periods, I would wait a few quarters to see how the company is doing and if its margins are improving before making a decision on the stock. If they aren't improving, I would take a pass on the stock as a low gross margin can be a cause for concern.

But if you're willing to take on some risk and trust that the company can fix those issues, it may be worth adding the stock to your portfolio as it does trade at a fairly low 11 times its estimated future profits. That's an incredibly low multiple for a tech stock, and it could justify taking on the risk as the upside could be massive if Supermicro proves its doubters wrong. This isn't a stock that is going to be suitable for risk-averse investors, but if you have a high risk tolerance, it could be worth buying today -- there's no need to wait for October.

IMO, another reason I don't believe the accusations by Hindenburg is that their research repeatedly cited former employees said and according to a former salesperson. I question the credibility of these sources, as they may hold a grudge against the company. Personally, I prefer to listen to the insights of higher-level executives, who likely have a more comprehensive understanding of the company's operations and intentions.

Since Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI) filed Form 12b-25 on August 30, 2024, they initially had until September 14, 2024, to file their 10-K, assuming they needed the full 15-day extension period. The SEC filing deadlines require that if the due date falls on a weekend or a holiday, the deadline is extended to the next business day. Since September 14, 2024, falls on a Saturday, the next business day would be Monday, September 16, 2024. Therefore, Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI) would have until then to file their 10-K if they are using the full extension period provided after the Form 12b-25 filing.

15 days is more than enough for a team of professional accountants to wrap up an audit. Audit work typically starts 6 months ahead of the deadline. There is no real excuse here for being late. Something is not right

Based upon the work done to date, the Company does not anticipate the 2024 Form 10-K will contain any material changes to its results for the fiscal year and quarter ended June 30, 2024 that were announced in the Companys press release dated August 6, 2024.
A 10-K cannot be filed on a weekend if the filing deadline is on a weekend or federal holiday. Instead, the filing deadline is extended to the next business day.

If the due date of a company's 12b-25 filing falls on a Saturday, the deadline is typically extended to the next business day, which would be Monday. In general, SEC filings do not fall on weekends or federal holidays, and the next business day becomes the due date.

Super Micro isnt alone in its tardiness: Early this year the number of public companies that filed late annual reports spiked 40% compared to 2023, according to a March report from Intelligize, which provides regulatory insights and analytics. 

The accounting talent shortage and increased reporting requirements have pressured companies and created a perfect storm leading to more late SEC filings.

Despite the questions surrounding the upcoming 10-K report, Super Micro's rapid growth is likely genuine. After all, its partner Nvidia continues to report triple-digit revenue growth, primarily because of the popularity of its AI chips, which often go into Super Micro's servers. Considering its growth rate and potential for more growth, I will buy SMCI shares whenever it became available at a reasonable valuation.
